divs: Sighting DetailsI was traveling to St.George Utah on the morning of dec.04,2007.I left Kingman,Az. at approx.2:10am.I was heading north on hiway 93 towards Las Vegas at approx.m.p.40 and approx.2:45am when the entire sky lit up above me.There had only been 2 other vehicles that I passed(they were heading south),and there was no traffic in front of me for at least10 miles.When the event happened I was traveling at 70 mph and immeadiately let off the gas and started slowing down.Hiway 93 runs thru the center of a long valley for close to 50 miles and is 20 miles across in places.At mp40 it is about 15 or 16 miles wide from peak to peak.I remember the sky lighting up so bright that I could see details in the landscape of the hills.Also there is a towing yard in this area and I could tell the colors on the parked vehicles.I tried to look out the window of my truck up towards the sky above me.Then I saw a large green fireball streaking towards the ground from the south to the north at about a 45 degree angle.I estimate at 200 to 500 ft it broke up into several dozen orange colored fragments some of which I believe hit the ground.(I did a quick search of the area a few days later but found nothing.)I stopped my truck,got out and walked around for a bit but the event was over,lasting about 7 or 8 seconds.Thirty miles up the road there is a police check point before crossing hoover dam,where they stop traffic and perform vehicle inspections.When I stopped they immeadiately asked me if I had seen the bright flash in the sky.They stated it lit up the entire southern hemisphere from there viewpoint.A friend was also traveling towards Kingman at the same time only he was about 140 miles east(around Flagstaff,Az.),and he saw the western sky light up and assumed it might be lightning although there was only high thin clouds at the time.I dont know what it was that was above me but Ihave to assume it was quite large and that it violently exploded some how up above me.I feel the green fireball and the fragments were just a small part of the event that took place that morning.It had to be quite large to be seen from 140 miles away.
